I start Radiotherapy in 3 months. Best of luck Chris, I hope we both do well !!!!!

Posts.Title: PSA Result or Doubling Time

Posts.Content: I have been waiting for my staging results and I know they have been available for about a week, the doctor has phoned me but as you can't be by the phone 24/7 I have missed him. I have been very anxious with all the waiting and I think most people would agree it drives you mad. I have tried to contact the doctor several times through his secretary and he was either in theatre or at a patient clinic which does make you think, far better that he is operating or treating a cancer patient if we have to wait then we have to wait !! It does not make him uncaring and suspect if he takes a while, he may be good and he may be extremely busy.

I have had my first Zoladex 3.6mg injection with no real side effects and an improvement in the waterworks department. My second injection will be next week then they will be every 3 months. My radiation therapy should start in April. Best of luck with your treatment Chris I hope we both have a good outcome.

Reading the posts some of you have treatment over long periods such as " external beam radiation, 5 weeks, 15 minutes a day, five days a week " Is it normal to try and carry on working through all this or is it too much. What can I expect ?

Posts.Title: Do You Keep Working ?

Posts.Content: Biopsy results noted focal involvement (see below) what does that mean ? Right prostatic biopsies show extensive involvement of two cores by prostatic adenocarcinoma with focal involvement of two further cores. The Gleason grade is 4+3=7 Left prostatic biopsies show involvement of two cores by deposits of adencarcinoma the largest deposit measuring 5mm The Gleason grade is 3+4=7

Posts.Title: What Does Focal Involvement Mean

Posts.Content: Hello gearloose I finished my radiation treatment in July and just like you I get hip pain. It can be on either side and if I have been sitting for some time I am also very stiff for a while, when I have been moving around for a bit it goes. I'm sure I have read that radiation can leave you with very small hairline bone cracks, could this give us arthritis or similar so soon......... I don't know !
Posts.Signature: Dec 2012 = PSA 61, Gleason 4+3=7, Staging=T3a Apr 2013 = Radiation treatment & hormone injections Nov 2013 = PSA 0.2 Feb 2014 = PSA 0.8 May 2014 = PSA 1.9
Posts.Title: Hip and leg pain could it be from Radation. Treatment

Posts.Content: Had the biopsy and get the results on the 23rd Nov so it's an anxious wait !! One thing I can't get my head round is baseline PSA. My GP recorded a PSA of 61 in May. During a stay in hospital in June for something unconnected they recorded a 53 PSA Out of hospital and GP done another PSA and it was 40. Referred to Urologist recently and another PSA showed 47. Everyone(except me)seems fairly relaxed about this, could my baseline PSA be so high. I think not and I think I will be a full member of this forum soon and having Dr Walsh's book as a Christmas present. Can you have high PSA's like this that are not enlarged prostates or infections and do not develop into PC, there are people on the forum that know a lot more about this subject than me and any comments would be welcome. I don't mind the visits and tests(has to be done)but don't you think it's the waiting that drives you up the wall !!
Posts.Title: Base Level PSA

Posts.Content: I live in England and we do have the National Health Service which is free at point of use and paid for out of our taxes. The treatment I have had has been great, I have no complaints but you do have to wait in the queue between appointments. I have read that the PSA test is not that accurate so could this just be the acceptable variation ?
Posts.Title: Base Level PSA

Posts.Content: I am 58 years old and will add a signature when I have more info. I was searching the web for answers and came across an article by the American association for cancer research.They have info that supports the theory that Aspirin will lower your PSA scores. I have had high blood pressure for some years and take a Bendroflumethiazide tablet and an Aspirin daily. After my PSA of 61 I had my hospital stay and was treated with Ciprofloxacin(no Aspirin) and my next PSA was 53. On leaving hospital I continued with Ciprofloxacin and resumed the daily Aspirin, the next PSA was 40. I have now finished the Ciprofloxacin but still take the Aspirin now the PSA is 47. Could the tablets have influenced the PSA swings ? Not by that much, probably a coincidence but I will soon know what's going on,the worst outcome for me will be if they can't find any causes for the high PSA's Something is causing them, they are not normal scores !!!!!
Posts.Title: Base Level PSA

Posts.Content: Thanks for all your replies I thought it would be Pc but when they actually confirm it it still leaves you in a state of shock. At 58 years old I don't know what to do, the final outcome is uncertain at this stage, should I retire, should I downsize to a smaller home I'm sure you have all been through this stage and I have decided to do nothing until I have more facts. My father and his 2 brothers all died with bowel cancer so I don't want to be too complacent. Hopefully my Bone scans & MRI are not too far off and I can meet with the consultant and decide on the way forward. I think I am leaning towards surgery as it's the gold standard especially with cancer in the family (although not prostate) and I will be guided by the professionals but it's my life at stake, do you think thats the right approach ?................. I value your opinions

Posts.Content: Ken, I share your frustration it would be nice to have a professional contact, I know they are busy but as a patient you are very anxious/concerned and waiting for the next appointment/result or is a real worry. Why can't you have a date/timeslot when you can speak about your case to someone, although you don't have Pc I can understand that you are still very concerned and obviously need to talk about future tests or whatever !!! I'm normally ok when I have a plan for the next step, but waiting for news that could be good or bad seems to take forever.

Posts.Title: Uncommunicative Medical Professionals

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by bigbrad2008 You can look at the data on recurrence (I had rads and hormones). The data I think shows that surgery is a bit better. HOWEVER, that data you see is based on old rad doses as the machines used when studies were started kina hit the other organs and the machines they use know are more targeted. So they have upped the rads doses. So take what you read with a grain of salt as we got higher doses and likely have better odds. what was your dre? any image evidence of outside of prostate? did you get imrt alone or brachiotherapy on top of imrt? Thanks for the reply Brad the dre showed a very hard left side with the right feeling normal. Non of the images showed evidence of spread and up till now I have only had IMRT.

The one thing that does stay in my mind though is the comment that there is a good chance it will return, there must be someone on the forum who has been in my position with similar stats. Would it be a good idea to continue the Hormone injections ?

Posts.Title: What Are The Chances Of PC Returning After Radiation Treatment

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by 35coupe Do you mind stating what side effects the radiation caused. Hello 35coupe I don't mind at all. The radiation treatment (every day for just under 6 weeks) was not a problem for me although I was a little tired I carried on going to work and drove the car as usual. Some patients I spoke to were a bit sore but fortunately I didn't have this issue. One thing that I did find hard was keeping a full bladder. They get you to drink water before your treatment and if the treatment is delayed you still have to try and keep the water in the bladder. I had a few problems with the Hormone injections but hopefully you are not on these. If you have any more questions just ask.
Posts.Signature: Dec 2012 = PSA 61, Gleason 4+3=7, Staging=T3a Apr 2013 = Radiation treatment & hormone injections Nov 2013 = PSA 0.2 Feb 2014 = PSA 0.8 May 2014 = PSA 1.9
Posts.Title: What Are The Chances Of PC Returning After Radiation Treatment

Posts.Content: I have recently finished my Radiation & Hormone treatment ( my PC was too advanced for an operation ) and my PSA has dropped from 61 to 0.2 I am naturally pleased with this result but having had such a high PSA I would like to know what are the chances that the PC will return. I have read everything I can find and I think there is a high probability it will come back within 5 years. I am 60 next year and although I had planned to carry on until I am 65 I would not want to retire and have the PC suddenly come back, it may not be so easy to control next time( if there is a next time ! ) Has anyone been in my position and if so what was the outcome ? All opinions are as usual very welcome. I would also like to say thanks for all the advice given to me by everyone on the forum over the last few months and I do hope all your treatments go well.
Posts.Signature: Dec 2012 = PSA 61, Gleason 4+3=7, Staging=T3a Apr 2013 = Radiation treatment & hormone injections Nov 2013 = PSA 0.2 Feb 2014 = PSA 0.8 May 2014 = PSA 1.9
Posts.Title: What Are The Chances Of PC Returning After Radiation Treatment

Posts.Content: Just had my staging results and there has been no spread to the bone as far as they can tell although it is spreading and might have penetrated the wall of the prostate. I have a staging category of T3A. Professionals are advising a radical prostatatectomy followed by radiation treatment. I am ok with this as I always favoured surgery(the gold standard)although I am more than a bit worried. Would you go open or robotic - why ? Any comments or advice welcome as are reasons for going another route.

Posts.Content: John T If the cancer has not penetrated the wall of the prostate then surely the surgery would be a success and if it had only just penetrated then the remainder could be mopped up with radiation treatment. I am open minded to the treatment and will discuss all of this when I meet with the relevant people.

Posts.Title: When Do You Stop Worrying !

Posts.Content: Finished my radiotherapy sessions in June last year and my first blood test showed a drop from 61 to 0.2 so I was naturally quite pleased thinking at 60 I have a lot more years to enjoy, and I might have ! I was speaking to someone I met at the hospital who was 77 with an initial PSA of 12 if I remember correctly and now his is 0.02 after his radiotherapy. Mine is ten times higher and something drove it to 61 in the first place, anyone with similar stats care to comment......... when can I stop worrying I think someone who knows a lot more about this than I do will say " the answer is probably never " so just get on with it !!

Posts.Title: When Do You Stop Worrying !

Posts.Content: First post for me, I am 58 and I have had problems for months and turned to the forum for advice as I am getting anxious with all the waiting !! About 6 months ago I had discitis which is a blood infection that attacks the discs of the spine. I had trouble walking and a lot of back pain but after 3 weeks in hospital with IV antibiotics I am now a lot better. During the investigations to find a cause I had a PSA test and the score was 61. Since leaving the hospital and finishing the medication I have had more PSA tests as the first was considered to be very high. My scores were 53, 40 and the latest was 47 !!! Could the discitis have any connection with the prostate issue has anyone experienced this ? Do the PSA scores mean PC or could it be an enlarged prostate ? I am going to have an ultrasound and prostate biopsy next and would be interested in peoples comments so I am better placed to ask the right questions when I go to the hospital. Any comments or advice would be most welcome...................thankyou.
Posts.Title: Discitis Then Raised PSA's

Posts.Content: Many thanks to you all for responding so quickly it's good to be able to talk to people with real experience of these problems. I will give you a bit more information and as before I would be pleased to receive any replies and info that you think may be useful. I had the spinal infection and it was treated successfully with Ciprofloxacin via intravenus drip, after leaving hospital I continued with Ciprofloxacin tablet(750mg)twice a day for another month and then the hospital informed me that there was no trace of the infection and my blood was completely clear. I was then referred by my doctor to a Urologist because of the raised PSA of 61. I have had a DRE and the Urologist said it was smooth and not lumpy and slightly enlarged but to a size he would expect for someone of my age. He asked me to go another six weeks without any medication to make sure the my hospital stay had nothing to do with the high PSA result. I have been out of hospital for 3 months now and the medication was stopped 8 weeks ago. I had another PSA test and it has gone from 40 to 47. The Urologist is arranging for me to have an Ultrasound and biopsy now and as you can see the wait was not an insurance issue but just to confirm my infection had nothing to do with my prostate issue(we think !!). Having read a lot on the subject I think it may be cancer so I am prepared for a bit of a journey and welcome comments from my Cancer Forum friends.
Posts.Title: Discitis Then Raised PSA's

Posts.Content: I have been reading a lot of case histories on the forum today. It seems a bit of a minefield with people having multiple negative biopsy's and still having PC. One thing that stands out is the number of people who get PC when they have PSA's under 10. As I stated earlier my prostate is enlarged but to a size that's normal for my age. I had no pain at all during the DRE, a clear urine sample and they seem to rule out an infection. My PSA's are 61, 53, 40 & 47 are we definately talking cancer here or could it just as easily be something else ?
Posts.Title: Discitis Then Raised PSA's

Posts.Content: Chrisjc, Don't worry about the biopsy, none of us wanted one but it's no big deal, I would have another 20 biopsy's if it helped sort me out. I had high PSA's and it turned out to be Cancer, thanks to the biopsy we know what weare dealing with !! Derek
Posts.Signature: Dec 2012 = PSA 61, Gleason 4+3=7, Staging=T3a Apr 2013 = Radiation treatment & hormone injections Nov 2013 = PSA 0.2 Feb 2014 = PSA 0.8 May 2014 = PSA 1.9
Posts.Title: going to hospital for test

Posts.Content: Still a newcomer but having read the forum over the past weeks I notice a few people are reluctant to have a biopsy. I have had a biopsy today which was prompted by a PSA of 47. Do not worry about having a biopsy, I had a 12 core biopsy and the pain was no more than being flicked by an elastic band and it took minutes to complete. I had antibiotics 1 hour before the procedure and will be taking them for another 3 days, I have also been told to drink plenty of water to flush things out. Not earth shattering information I know but I thought it might be useful for other newbies like myself. On to the next step, I have to wait for the results !!!!!
Posts.Title: Have The Biopsy !

Posts.Content: Ken, Glad you got to speak with the Urologist. Good luck with the next biopsy in 6 months, it gives you more time to educate yourself on the subject. Hopefully it will always be a negative biopsy for you, do keep in touch. Derek
Posts.Signature: Dec 2012 = PSA 61, Gleason 4+3=7, Staging=T3a Apr 2013 = Radiation treatment & hormone injections Nov 2013 = PSA 0.2 Feb 2014 = PSA 0.8 May 2014 = PSA 1.9
Posts.Title: HI Grade PIN

Posts.Content: Now I have confirmed Pc I am starting to look at the bigger picture. My father and his 2 brothers died of bowel cancer and I do worry if there could be a connection between bowel & prostate cancer. I don't want to be paranoid or complacent and I will be seeing my doctor next week so I will mention it but does anyone have any opinions or points to make. I am waiting for results of staging so now might be the time to put this concern to one side Just had Dr Walshs book plenty to read about possible treatments......... well worth buying.
Posts.Signature: Dec 2012 = PSA 61, Gleason 4+3=7, Staging=T3a Apr 2013 = Radiation treatment & hormone injections Nov 2013 = PSA 0.2 Feb 2014 = PSA 0.8 May 2014 = PSA 1.9
Posts.Title: Any Connection Between Prostate And Bowel Cancer ?

Posts.Content: Are you casually looking through the posts for info, you know you are fine with only the odd twinge now and then so there can't be much wrong with you. I was like that at the beginning of this year, never off sick from work and felt fairly fit, I never went to see the doctor. I had noticed that I had lost pressure when I went to the toilet and it would sometimes be a bit stop start but I was 58 years old and things are bound to slow down as you get a bit older, it was not a problem. To cut a long story short I went to the doctors for something unrelated, I had a PSA blood test and now a lot further down the road I am faced with a fairly agressive cancer. Prostate cancer marches on unoticed you may not have many(or any)symtoms but if you are reading this then there must be something on your mind. Go to your doctor have a simple PSA blood test, it may be nothing and on the plus side you will have a baseline PSA to refer to in the future. The blood test is no problem. You might have a rectal examination again no problem. Later if Pc is suspected you may have a biopsy and it is nothing to fear from my experience. Reading the posts on this forum has helped me a lot, someone will have had experience of whatever concerns you. I am now waiting for staging results and when I have them I will turn to my friends on the forum again for advice. Merry Christmas and thankyou for all your help along the way. Derek
Posts.Signature: Dec 2012 = PSA 61, Gleason 4+3=7, Staging=T3a Apr 2013 = Radiation treatment & hormone injections Nov 2013 = PSA 0.2 Feb 2014 = PSA 0.8 May 2014 = PSA 1.9
Posts.Title: Are You Just Looking Could YOU have ProstateCancer

Posts.Content: I have a plan after a recent PSA of 49, a Gleason of 4+3=7 and Staging of T3a It is too advanced for surgery, I am starting hormone therapy and will soon start radiation therapy. Have many of you been this route and was it successful ? Can you continue working for the duration of the treatment ? Will there be many side effects during the therapy ? Can there be long term problems after the therapy ? What are the chances of it returning ?
Posts.Title: Decision Made

Posts.Content: Lancepease - Yes I am from the UK Anyone who has been through this. Is the radiation treatment normally successful and if it does not eliminate all of the PC is it just a case of doing it again ?
Posts.Title: Decision Made
